top_comment.text:
I know Einstein's last words, I am the first to know, and now you all know. 
"In essence, the conflict that exists today is no more than an old-style 
struggle for power, once again presented to mankind in semireligious 
trappings. The difference is that, this time, the development of atomic 
power has imbued the struggle with a ghostly character; for both parties 
know and admit that, should the quarrel deteriorate into actual war, 
mankind is doomed. Despite this knowledge, statesmen in responsible 
positions on both sides continue to employ the well-known technique of 
seeking to intimidate and demoralize the opponent by marshaling superior 
military strength. They do so even though such a policy entails the risk of 
war and doom. Not one statesman in a position of responsibility has dared 
to pursue the only course that holds out any promise of peace, the course 
of supranational security, since for a statesman to follow such a course 
would be tantamount to political suicide. Political passions, once they 
have been fanned into flame, exact their victims..."﻿

top_comment.text:
"the universe is huge" yes it is, and its questionable why we insist on 
including it in our idea of the "world" and insist on making ourselves feel 
insignificant and small. It's the perfect example of the human's selfesteem 
selfdestructive way of thinking, our whole life we pretend to strive to 
perfection and significance while purposely extending our goal by making 
the world bigger and our accomplishes less significant. Once it's possible 
to go see the moon for yourself your cultural trip to India won't be 
interesting anymore, In a way it's selfish and selfdestructive to aim so 
high for ourselves. It's one of the many reasons I insist we focus on our 
own little planet instead of continueing this romantic way of thinking that 
will systematically keep our selfimage down. ﻿
top_comment.author: Terri Tyrian

comments.text:
+Carson McCarty so do I, I'm already very happy someone responded to 
initiate a healthy and intelligent conversation. I'm personally somewhat 
uncomfortable with how much we insist on going into the universe, mostly 
cause theres this mentality among a few of us to say "if our own planet is 
lost, maybe some day we can go to the next". But that beside the point.

Curiosity I usually don't see as a bad thing, but we do live in a society 
where the expectations of ourselves and others having of us are so tight 
and almost ruthless and for the ignorant sake of it we still can't figure 
out why the amount of burnouts increase and this curiosity to the universe 
is a perfect example of how our need to push further (whether thats in 
finding new things or becoming bigger as a person or as a society) displays 
the likeminded impulse to ask more of ourselves.
From the start of time we went to working only an hour a day and spending 
the rest of our time having fun to the kind of life we have now and that to 
me makes things as crimes, drugabuse and various psychological issues no 
mystery, but again, thats beside the point.
I know the two seem unrelated, but think about it, they say if technology 
stops advancing we'd "stop evolving" and with that logic die out, but I 
don't think you can say that, what's wrong with sticking to digital screens 
instead of striving for holografic touch screens.
At the end my point is, that is it to wonder why we expand? curiosity is 
one thing, but im not convinced its just that, I maybe dare to say it is a 
form of denial, to counter something else, I just wouldn't know what.

Id love to hear your thoughts on this, and feel free to correct me, 
critisize the theory, its the best way to expand my horizon (ha)
comments.author: Terri Tyrian

comments.text:
Hmm. I kind of get what you're saying, but I can't compleyely agree. "by 
making the world bigger." That depends on what you think of as "the world." 
The universe as we know it is seemingly vastless, we did not simply make 
that up. The point of aiming so highly is not to destruct our society, but 
it is because humans, as a species, have a natural-born curiosity. It's 
actually talked about in one of Vsauce's recent videos. Your point of 
thinking at this point may be something similar to, "well, curiosity killed 
that cat." However, you may be surprised to know that it's only half the 
quote you know. The other half is, "curiosity killed the cat, but 
satisfaction brought it back." By the way, if you found these last few 
sentences pointless, I do not blame you. I just love sharing that 
knowledge. (:

comments.text:
+clowntrooper61 All that stuff you said about the moon crashing into the 
earth and the carbon dioxide and oceans is all theory, and nothing more. 
 Secondly, there is fossil evidence AGAINST evolution, and none for it. 
 Also, macroevolution (e.g. fish to monkey to human) is completely 
impossible as all living things (even the simplest of all) are far too 
complex to change one mutation at a time to a different species.  In other 
words, the transitional species (the ones that are crossed to get from fish 
to monkey to human) could never survive or reproduce long enough to 
complete the transition to the next species.  While microevolution (changes 
within a species) is proven to exist, macroevolution is logically unsound 
and proven to be false.  Also, your argument that people could make the 
car, the house, etc. is so flawed it shows that you don't even understand 
the argument you attempted to refute.  The car is a metaphor for the earth 
and the fact that it contains the perfect conditions for life.  Claiming 
that "people could've made the car" is either claiming that aliens made the 
earth (an argument with no basis and which doesn't solve the root problem) 
or admitting that God made the earth.  Finally, even if macroevolution were 
possible and had any supporting evidence, it doesn't explain how the first 
life came to be.  There is absolutely no scientifically sound and 
reasonable explanation for the beginning of life except for intelligent 
design.  You mentioned that the Bible never claimed that God was ever born. 
 This is so because God is infinite, or eternal.  He exists outside of 
time, which itself didn't even exist until the universe began.  God has no 
beginning because he existed before the very concept of beginnings began. 
 All other arguments against the concept of God I saw you make were 
misguided at best, and showed in you a severe stubbornness and an adamant 
refusal to learn.  In fact, from what I saw, I think you didn't even read 
the comments you attempted to refute.  Christianity is based largely in 
fact and reason, more so than anything else.  The debate is not between 
religion and science, but between good science and bad science; between 
acceptance and stubbornness.
comments.author: Joseph Rogers

comments.text:
+Bush Vo   Despite what was widely reported in the media (which always 
deform scientific fact to get more sensational headlines), voyager 1 has 
NOT left the solar system. It has left the heliosphere, and that 's a big 
difference :
The heliosphere is a "bubble" around the sun, where solar wind is blocked 
by "galactic wind" (the various dilute gases our solar system goes through 
as it orbits the galaxy) it is roughly 90 astronomical units from the sun 
(that is, 90 times the average sun-earth distance).
The edge of the solar system is where the sun's attraction becomes 
dominated by that of nearby stars. It is located roughly 125 000 
astronomical units away from the sun.
Voyager 1 is currently 129 AU from the sun, that is 0.1% of the way to the 
edge of the solar system. It won't leave it before tens of thousands of 
years, and won't reach any other stellar system before 40 000 years at 
least. And even when it does, it will be a grain of sand in the vastness of 
space, 3 billions of times smaller than a bottle in the pacific ocean!

comments.text:
In the season 1911/1912 Amundsen and Scott led two expeditions to South 
Pole. The one led by Amundsen was the first one ever to reach South Pole.

After Scott's retreat from the pole in January 1912, the location remained 
unvisited for nearly 18 years(!): on 28 November 1929, US Navy Commander 
Richard E. Byrd and three others completed the first aircraft flight over 
the South Pole.

Twenty-seven years later (31 October 1956), Rear-Admiral George J. Dufek 
became the first person to set foot on the pole since Scott!

Now you know why it is not unusual that we have not returned to the Moon. 
Yet.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
On December 17th, 1977,
Gary Gilmore was executed for murder.

He was the first prisoner executed
by the United States after a

10-year suspension of the practice.
When asked if he had any

last words, he simply replied
"let's do it."

Years later, advertising executive Dan Wieden
adapted those words into
a slogan, that is now more widely known

than Gary Gilmore.
Last words

are powerful.
They are the final statement, a person's entire life has
been leading up to.

One last chance to go on record
before obliteration.
We don't know Albert Einstein's

last words.
He spoke them in German
to a nurse who only knew English,
They're lost.
But what will be

our first words?
The first words

from earth extraterrestrials out there
might hear from us.

We have been broadcasting signals
with radio waves

wirelessly through the air for more than
one hundred years.

Under the right conditions,
those signals can leak into space
and keep going outward at the speed of light

through our galaxy, through the universe.
Current human technology would struggle
to tune into regular TV and radio broadcasts from

as near as Mars.
But perhaps other intelligent beings out there

would fare better and could point there
instruments at earth

and hear us.
If so, what would the
earliest thing be that they could receive?
Our cosmic first

words.
Well, the

earliest signal, robust enough to be
picked up light years away,
might have come from Hitler.
His 1936 broadcasting

of the Summer Olympics used powerful
enough radio equipment to reach
forty-one countries,

making it a contender for what listening
extraterrestrials could receive as,
to them, Earth's first words.
Within the last 50 years or so, broadcast signals

in general, have become stronger
than Hitler's Olympics
and are better candidates for being intercepted.

The earliest of them have traveled
50 light years away from Earth.
Altogether they have entertained billions of
people and by now about 2,000 stars.
The 133 brightest of which are shown

here.
So far, Martin Luther King JR's

"I have a dream" speech
has traveled as far as the furthest
on the diagram µAra, which has

four known planets.
In six years,

our first words on the Moon
will pass by µAra's

system.
"That's one small step for man,

one giant leap for mankind."
Those words were spoken by Neil

Armstrong,
seen here a few years before his death

with Eugene Cernan,
the most recent and currently
last man to have walked on the surface of the Moon.
On December 14th, 1972,

before climbing back into the lunar module,
Cernan spoke
our, as of today, last words on the Moon.
"We leave as we came and,
God willing, as we shall return, with peace,

and hope for all mankind."
Of course,
once inside the lunar module, the crew kept

talking, meaning that technically
the very last words humans have said

on the surface of the Moon were a
countdown spoken by Harrison

Jack Schmitt.
"Three, two, one."
We haven't been back to the Moon

since.
But hold on. What were the first words
spoken on the surface of the Moon

really?
Armstrong's giant

leap statement is a good answer,
but what counts as being
on the Moon if touchdown

counts? Then the first words spoken on the
Moon go not to Armstrong but to Buzz Aldrin,
who, on feeling at least one of the landing pads
softly settle onto the lunar soil, spoke

this immortal description:
"contact light."
We are pumping broadcasts in the space
as an ever expanding sphere of radio waves.

But here's something humbling.
Even while growing at the speed of light,
Earth's radio sphere is puny.

This is our galaxy, the Milky Way.
Comparatively,
the distance our radio signals, our voice
has traveled is this big.
The universe is huge.

How the heck are you supposed
to be remembered in it?
Utter last words that stick around after you die?

Well, you may have heard
the famous quote from Banksy
"They say you die twice.
One time when you stop breathing and a second time,
a bit later on, when somebody says your name

for the last time."
But your anonymous influence continues

long after that, right?
I mean, people may stop saying your name,
but, for instance, if you have kids and they have kids
and so on and so on, you continue on,

in a way.
Maybe just genetically, not by name.

Well, people have tried.
The world record

for most children passed
out of one single woman

belongs to Mrs. Feodor Vassilyev.
She had
16 pairs of twins, 7 sets of triplets
and 4 sets of quadruplets for a grand total

of 69 children.
As for being a biological

father, that takes less time.
The documented record
for most children fathered by one man is held
by Ismail Ibn Sharif, who is estimated to have had
more than 900 children with multiple women.
But children—or not—in a feedback system like
earth or life, cause-and-effect
are complicated and never ending.

Remember the double pendulums
from this video? A small difference

in the initial conditions of a system
can lead to enormously

different outcomes later.
On Tuesday

I'm flying from London to Los Angeles.
The plane will be flown by pilots who
can steer it toward the correct runway
in the United States, but if the airplane needed to be
aimed from London and sent on a straight shot,
now, things would need to be very specific.
Misaiming just one degree to the left

at the beginning would send
the plane not to Los Angeles

but nearly 160 kilometres south
to Tijuana, Mexico.

Your name and your last words might
eventually be forgotten, but your status
as an initial condition for the universe's
future is already happening.
Bach died before he could complete

The Art of Fugue.
The peace ends abruptly

during Contrapunctus XIV.
So, composers continue

reconstructing it.
For that reason, it is

uniquely alive.
Speaking new

last words all the time,
as new people meet it

and finish it in their own way.
Likewise, no matter how
cool or lame and small

you feel, you will continue.
Your impact will be remembered, mathematics

guarantees it.
Even if like Bach you leave things
unfinished.
And as always,
thanks for wa...
